awd_titl_txt: Enantioselective Fluorescent Recognition of Amino Alcohols and Catalyst Screening
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms-B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Lin Pu of the Department of Chemistry at University of Virginia is developing new molecular sensors for the recognition of chiral organic molecules.  These sensors can be used to facilitate high throughput screening of asymmetric reactions.  As these asymmetric reactions are widely used in fine chemical preparations such as pharmaceutical drugs and their intermediates, these sensors can increase the efficiency of their preparation and perhaps reduce cost.  In this project, students and other researchers receive education and training in diverse areas including organic, analytical, and materials chemistry.  The research team is also active in outreach activities to K-12 students in science and technology. 

The molecular probes of high fluorine contents are being designed and synthesized for enantioselective fluorescent recognition.  These probes can form covalent bonds with the targeted chiral substrates and bring them into the fluorous phase for fluorescent detection.  When these materials are used to screen asymmetric reactions, their fluorescence responses toward the reaction products can be measured in the fluorous phase, and this may minimize the interference from other components in the reaction media since normal organic and inorganic materials cannot be dissolved in the fluorous phase.  In comparison to the traditional chromatography-based methods, this fluorescence measurement method may be much faster and more well suited to high throughput analysis.  This strategy could facilitate the discovery of chiral catalysts and reagents for the asymmetric synthesis of chiral compounds with diverse applications in areas such as biochemical, pharmaceutical and agricultural industries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project is to conduct the enantioselective discrimination of amino alcohols, amino acids and other chiral compounds by developing fluorescent probes in the fluorous phase, aqueous solution and organic media.  The application of these probes in the screening of chiral catalysts for asymmetric synthesis has also been explored.  These probes have provided new methods for the rapid analysis of chiral organic molecules of biological and synthetic importance.

      For example, we conducted a screening of catalysts for the asymmetric reaction of 1,2-epoxycyclohexane with isopropylamine to generate the chiral amino alcohol (R,R)-1 by using the two enantiomeric and highly fluorinated fluorescent probes (S)- and (R)-2 to evaluate the reaction yield and enantioselectivity (Chart 1).  The fluorescence responses were measured in the fluorous phase which can minimize the interference of other reaction components.  The catalyst screening using the fluorescent probes led to the discovery of a more enantioselective and efficient method for the desymmetrization of 1,2-epoxycyclohexane with isopropylamine to form the corresponding chiral amino alcohol.  This work presents a novel method to conduct catalyst screening for asymmetric synthesis and has potential to become a high throughput process.

     We have designed and synthesized several fluorescent probes for chemoselective as well as enantioselective recognition of certain amino acid enantiomers.  For example, micelles made of an amphiphilic diblock copolymer are used to encapsulate the water-insoluble (S)-1,1'-binaphthyl-based monoaldehydes (S)-3 for the chemoselective and enantioselective fluorescent recognition of L-tryptophan in the presence of Zn2+ in aqueous solution (Chart 2).  (S)-5 is designed for the selective recognition of histidine.  (S)-7 shows greatly enhanced fluorescence in the presence of L-glutamic acid and L-aspartic acid, but produces no or little fluorescent response toward their opposite enantiomers and other amino acids.  (R)-9 in combination with Zn2+ shows greatly enhanced fluorescence in the presence of L-serine.  The structures 4, 6, 8 and 10 are proposed to explain the selective interactions of these probes with the corresponding substrates.  These findings have demonstrated that highly selective fluorescent identification of a specific amino acid enantiomer can be achieved by incorporating certain functional groups at the designated locations of the 1,1'-binaphthyls.  The binaphthyl core structure of these probes provides both chirality source and highly tunable fluorescence property.  Matching the structure and chirality of these probes with those of the specific amino acid enantiomers can generate structurally rigid reaction products and give rise to greatly enhanced fluorescence.  The strategies of this work can be further expanded to develop fluorescent probes for the specific identification of chiral molecules of interests. 

     We synthesized the red-light emitting ﬂuorescent probe (R)-11 (Chart 3).  In the presence of Zn2+, this compound was found to exhibit good enantioselective fluorescence enhancement when treated with a variety of amino acids in aqueous solution.  This probe in combination with the green-light emitting probe (S)-12 formed a pseudoenantiomeric sensor pair because of their opposite enantioselectivity.  This pair were used to visually and semiquantitatively determine the enantiomeric compositions of amino acids.  For example, when a 1:1 mixture of (R)-11 and (S)-12 was treated with Zn(OAc)2 and the histidine samples of various enantiomeric compositions, the color of the mixtures changed from green to yellow, orange and red under a UV lamp which allowed a quick quantification of the enantiomeric composition.  This is the first example of using fluorescence to visually quantify the enantiomeric composition of chiral compounds.  It provides a simple and efficient method to analyze chiral compounds of biological and synthetic importance.

    This project has provided training for graduate and undergraduate students in the areas of synthesis, catalysis and optical analysis.  A number of research papers (18) have been published in reputable journals to disseminate the laboratory's findings to the wider audience.  Those involved in the project have also taken part in the Chemistry LEAD (Chemistry Learning through Experimentation and Demonstration) program at the University of Virginia (UVA).  This program aims to deliver hands-on chemistry education to elementary school students using inquiry-based methods.  Graduate students from the UVA Department of Chemistry, including those within this project, have actively participated in this program.  Their involvement has included frequent visits to local K-5 classrooms, where they have conducted brief experiments.  These experiments have effectively engaged the elementary school students in interactive chemistry investigations.  Additionally, the outreach group has been responsible for arranging annual chemistry camps within the UVA Department of Chemistry, catering to the younger generation.


Last Modified: 08/29/2023
Modified by: Lin Pu

por.por_txt_cntn:
The major goal of this project is to conduct the enantioselective discrimination of amino alcohols, amino acids and other chiral compounds by developing fluorescent probes in the fluorous phase, aqueous solution and organic media.  The application of these probes in the screening of chiral catalysts for asymmetric synthesis has also been explored.  These probes have provided new methods for the rapid analysis of chiral organic molecules of biological and synthetic importance.

      For example, we conducted a screening of catalysts for the asymmetric reaction of 1,2-epoxycyclohexane with isopropylamine to generate the chiral amino alcohol (R,R)-1 by using the two enantiomeric and highly fluorinated fluorescent probes (S)- and (R)-2 to evaluate the reaction yield and enantioselectivity (Chart 1). The catalyst screening using the fluorescent probes led to the discovery of a more enantioselective and efficient method for the desymmetrization of 1,2-epoxycyclohexane with isopropylamine to form the corresponding chiral amino alcohol.  This work presents a novel method to conduct catalyst screening for asymmetric synthesis and has potential to become a high throughput process.

     We have designed and synthesized several fluorescent probes for chemoselective as well as enantioselective recognition of certain amino acid enantiomers.  For example, micelles made of an amphiphilic diblock copolymer are used to encapsulate the water-insoluble (S)-1,1'-binaphthyl-based monoaldehydes (S)-3 for the chemoselective and enantioselective fluorescent recognition of L-tryptophan in the presence of Zn2+ in aqueous solution (Chart 2).  (S)-5 is designed for the selective recognition of histidine.  (S)-7 shows greatly enhanced fluorescence in the presence of L-glutamic acid and L-aspartic acid, but produces no or little fluorescent response toward their opposite enantiomers and other amino acids.  (R)-9 in combination with Zn2+ shows greatly enhanced fluorescence in the presence of L-serine.  The structures 4, 6, 8 and 10 are proposed to explain the selective interactions of these probes with the corresponding substrates.  These findings have demonstrated that highly selective fluorescent identification of a specific amino acid enantiomer can be achieved by incorporating certain functional groups at the designated locations of the 1,1'-binaphthyls.  The binaphthyl core structure of these probes provides both chirality source and highly tunable fluorescence property.  Matching the structure and chirality of these probes with those of the specific amino acid enantiomers can generate structurally rigid reaction products and give rise to greatly enhanced fluorescence.  The strategies of this work can be further expanded to develop fluorescent probes for the specific identification of chiral molecules of interests. 

     We synthesized the red-light emitting ﬂuorescent probe (R)-11 (Chart 3).  In the presence of Zn2+, this compound was found to exhibit good enantioselective fluorescence enhancement when treated with a variety of amino acids in aqueous solution.  This probe in combination with the green-light emitting probe (S)-12 formed a pseudoenantiomeric sensor pair because of their opposite enantioselectivity.  This pair were used to visually and semiquantitatively determine the enantiomeric compositions of amino acids.  For example, when a 1:1 mixture of (R)-11 and (S)-12 was treated with Zn(OAc)2 and the histidine samples of various enantiomeric compositions, the color of the mixtures changed from green to yellow, orange and red under a UV lamp which allowed a quick quantification of the enantiomeric composition.  This is the first example of using fluorescence to visually quantify the enantiomeric composition of chiral compounds.  It provides a simple and efficient method to analyze chiral compounds of biological and synthetic importance.

    This project has provided training for graduate and undergraduate students in the areas of synthesis, catalysis and optical analysis.  A number of research papers (18) have been published in reputable journals to disseminate the laboratory's findings to the wider audience.  Those involved in the project have also taken part in the Chemistry LEAD (Chemistry Learning through Experimentation and Demonstration) program at the University of Virginia (UVA).  This program aims to deliver hands-on chemistry education to elementary school students using inquiry-based methods.  Graduate students from the UVA Department of Chemistry, including those within this project, have actively participated in this program.  Their involvement has included frequent visits to local K-5 classrooms, where they have conducted brief experiments.  These experiments have effectively engaged the elementary school students in interactive chemistry investigations.  Additionally, the outreach group has been responsible for arranging annual chemistry camps within the UVA Department of Chemistry, catering to the younger generation.
